name: Tapejara
overview: Tapejara is a aerial reptile currently documented from Early Cretaceous (112 million years ago) in South America. Current interpretation suggests a omnivore feeding profile. It is typically classified as Pterosaur. Evidence quality for Tapejara is currently limited by specimen completeness and historical naming complexity. Dino-pedia tracks this taxon with conservative wording so future specimen-level studies can be integrated without overwriting uncertain claims.

funFacts: Its fossils are used to refine modern paleoart and biomechanical models.

Growth stage likely changed ecological role and behavior.

researchContext.evidenceBase: Tapejara is represented by published fossil material, but completeness and diagnostic overlap can limit high-confidence biological reconstruction.
researchContext.currentLimits: Several ecological and life-history traits remain inferential rather than directly measured for this taxon.
researchContext.nextDataNeeded: Priority evidence includes better-preserved cranial/postcranial overlap, robust stratigraphic control, and specimen-linked morphometrics.
researchContext.revisionOutlook: Interpretation is expected to improve as new finds and reanalyses clarify taxonomy and anatomy.
